Dear Katrina Dahl Edmon:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section CCI Rule 400.4158
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(iv)Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a
youth’s background or appearance or mental state. Yelling,
threats, ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Supervisor 1 was cussing, name calling, and making threats
towards Youth A while Youth A was making his phone call.
Investigation Complaint 1 was interviewed on 1/25/24. Complainant 1 reported
there was a recording she had of the allegations and sent this to
me. There was no other information that she provided.
I spoke to Administrator 1 on 1/25/24, allegations were
discussed. No new information was provided.
The date of the alleged incident is 1/24/24. The staff that were
present for the incident were Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2, Staff 1
and Staff 2. Youth A is the alleged victim according to the
allegations. No other staff or youth were present. None of the
staff or supervisors reported they left the unit or were distracted
2

during the incident. It is to be noted that Youth A was not making a
“scheduled” phone call. Youth A had brought an unauthorized
phone into the unit and was secretly talking to someone in his
bedroom. Youth A placed the phone on his bed to engage with the
staff. The phone call was still connected throughout the
interaction.
Interviews:
Supervisor 1
I interviewed Supervisor 1 on 2/1/24. Supervisor 1 reported he
worked on 1/24/24. Supervisor 1 reported he was called to the unit
on 1/24/24 to help due to Youth A becoming verbally aggressive.
Supervisor 1 reported he used “colorful language” with Youth A on
1/24/24. He described this as using profanity but not cussing at
Youth A. Supervisor 1 reported he used the “F” word in the
conversation. Supervisor 1 reported he did not name call Youth A
or threaten Youth A.
Staff 1
Staff 1 reported Youth A was upset and threatening Staff 2,
Supervisor 1, and Supervisor 2. Staff 1 reported Supervisor 1 was
attempting to deescalate Youth A. Staff 1 reported Supervisor 1
was respectful, had a normal tone and was explaining the
program to Youth A. Staff 1 reported Youth A called them “mother
fuckers,” but no one said anything back to him. Staff 1 reported
none of the staff were disrespectful to Youth A and none of the
staff used profanity towards Youth A or in their conversation with
Youth A.
Supervisor 2
Supervisor 2 reported Youth A was upset concerning a computer
that was confiscated from him. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A was
threatening and using profanity towards staff. Supervisor 2
reported Supervisor 1 was deescalating Youth A verbally.
Supervisor 2 reported none of the staff disrespected Youth A,
threatened Youth A or used profanity towards Youth A. Supervisor
2 reported he thought the team of staff did a good job
deescalating the situation. Supervisor 2 reported he thought the
team reacted to Youth A well and handled themselves well.
Staff 2
Staff 2 reported Youth A was threatening staff and using profanity
towards staff. Staff 2 reported Supervisor 2 had walked back and
forth in the unit but did not say anything to Youth A. Staff 2
reported Staff 1 never said anything to Youth A. Staff 2 reported
3

Supervisor 1 attempted to deescalate Youth A. Staff 2 reported
Supervisor 1 did not show signs of hostility nor did he threaten
Youth A or use profanity. Staff 2 reported Supervisor 1 was never
disrespectful to Youth A. Staff 2 was told there was audio of the
incident that occurred. Staff 2 maintained that no one was
aggressive, or used profanity, or was disrespectful to Youth A.
Youth A:
Youth A reported he was upset on 1/24/24 due to his computer
being taken from him. Youth A reported he had snuck a phone
into the unit and was talking to his dad in his bedroom. He heard
staff talking about him outside of his bedroom, so he went out.
Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2, Staff 1, and Staff 2 were all present.
Youth A reported he was upset with them and started yelling at
them to give him his computer. Youth A reported he could not
remember all of the conversation or the specific words but
summarized that Supervisor 1 threatened to physically harm him.
Youth A reported Staff 1 threatened to “slap him.” Youth A
reported he couldn’t remember if Supervisor 2 said anything.
Youth A reported Staff 2 did not say anything.
Recorded Phone Conversation:
Complainant 1 had a recording of the conversation between Youth
A and Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2, Staff 1 and Staff 2. This
recording is from 1/24/24. Administrator 1 verified the voice on the
phone to be Supervisor 1 when he listened to the audio. Staff 1,
Staff 2, Supervisor 1, and Supervisor 2 reported Supervisor 1 was
the staff member verbally attempting to deescalate Youth A. Youth
A Reported Supervisor 1 was the main staff talking to him.
The audio revealed Youth A threatening and using profanity
towards staff. The recording also revealed Supervisor 1 raising his
voice at Youth A, using profanity towards Youth A, and
threatening Youth A. Staff 1 also used profanity towards Youth A.
The following are comments Supervisor 1 stated to Youth A:
• “What other computer did I take? Mother fucker, I took? Get
the fuck on.”
• “What the fuck am I supposed to do? Have I ever fucked
you over…”
• “People always taking your shit…(unclear ending)”
• “I have a right to be mad because I respected you in every
way but you didn’t respect me. You talk about people taking
your shit, I didn’t take shit from you.”
• “If you don’t want to talk, don’t talk, I’ll shut the fuck up, if
you hit me, I’ll eat it, make the police report and then catch
your mother fucking ass off campus.”
4

Staff 1 responded to Youth A calling her a “mother fucker” by
stating, “I ain’t no mother fucker.”
Neither Supervisor 2 nor Staff 2 was heard in the audio.
Documents:
MCHS Family of Services Program Statement
The treatment philosophy. Is based on a trauma-focused, whole
system approach to the therapeutic milieu…Our major goal is to
provide treatment that effectively meets the emotional, cognitive,
social, and developmental needs of the youth in care. Treatment
teams utilize their relationships with the young persons and
families to empower them to find solutions to their problems and
maximize their potential.
Analysis Although all four staff interviewed reported they handled the
situation well with Youth A, it is clear from audio recording that
Supervisor 1 was yelling at Youth A and used profanity towards
Youth A and threatened Youth A’s physical wellbeing. Staff 1
responded back to Youth A using profanity.
Consultation: Supervisor 1 is a facility manager for the agency.
Supervisor 2 is the supervisor for the unit. The unit serves an
abuse and neglect population. It would benefit the agency to
evaluate the roles they have personnel in and whether they are
fulfilling these roles. It would also benefit the agency to evaluate if
this type of environment is fulfilling a trauma informed
environment.
Conclusion Violation Established

Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
Description program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency is not picking up youth after school and transporting
them back to the facility as their program statement outlines.
The agency is not following their search policy.
Investigation Allegation #1: The agency is not transporting youth after school
to the unit as program statement outlines.
Interviews:
Administrator 1
Administrator 1 reported Youth A walks home unsupervised from
school and this was described as their common daily practice.
Supervisor 2
Supervisor 2 reported the youth walk home from public schools
unsupervised.
Youth A:
Youth A reported he walks back to the agency from school
unsupervised.
Documents Reviewed:
I reviewed the MCHS Family of Services Program Statement:
Education Services: For youth who are outside of the grades
served by FLA, students have the option of attending in person or
virtual school in the community or continuing in their home school
if distance allows. Youth will be transported to and from school by
MCHS staff.
Allegation #2: The agency is not following their search policy,
specifically documenting searches and completing them
consistently in the same manner.
9

Interviews:
Administrator 1
Administrator 1 reported the agency does not have documentation
for the searches for Youth A written on the Personal and Room
Search Forms. Administrator 1 reported they should be
completing searches on youth in this unit.
Supervisor 1
Supervisor 1 reported the youth are to be searched when they
come to the unit from school. Supervisor 1 reported the search
should be to have them pull their pockets out, put hats inside out,
go around their waistbands and ankle cuffs, remove shoes and
socks and open their backpacks.
Staff 1
Staff 1 reported they are currently doing searches on youth when
they enter the unit. Staff 1 reported someone is picking up the
youth from school and drops them off at the unit. Once they get to
the unit, they ask the youth if they have permission to search
them. Staff 1 reported they “pat” the youth down on the outside of
their clothing and then have the youth open up their own
backpack. Staff 1 reported they do not have the youth take
anything out of their backpack, but staff look into their backpacks.
Staff 1 reported searching youth started about two months ago.
Staff1 reported they have found lighters, computers and phone
chargers.
Supervisor 2
Supervisor 2 reported they search all youth when they return to
the cottage from school. Supervisor 2 reported they use a “wand”
to wand the youth. Supervisor 2 reported they have youth take
their coats off and remove any metal they may have on them.
They then wand them with the metal detector wand. Supervisor 2
reported they had to have some sort of probable cause in order to
search them. Supervisor 2 reported they now do because the
youth are getting paraphernalia into the cottages. Supervisor 2
reported they have been searching now for two months.
Supervisor 2 reported after they wand the youth, they then have
the youth open their backpacks and look inside them. Supervisor
2 reported they do not have the youth empty their backpacks and
do not pat the youth down or have them remove items of clothing
(shoes and socks) or check waistbands.
10

Staff 2
Staff 2 reported staff are now completing searches on youth. Staff
2 did not know the time frame this has been occurring. Staff 2
reported he pats them on the outside of their clothing and has the
youth open their backpacks for him to look into it.
Documents:
I reviewed the Residential Treatment Overview: Section E.
Number 8. Searches.
All residents can be searched upon return to campus as follows:
upon return from school…probable cause…
Level 1 Search: this is a soft search. This is routine search that
occurs upon return to the resident’s cottage from an unsupervised
outing, from an unsupervised visit, or off grounds school
attendance. Level 1 always occurs prior to a Level 2 Search.
• Ask the person to flip out the inside of pockets.
• Ask the young person to empty backpack.
• Allow staff to visually inspect backpack as needed.
Level 2 Search: This is a more restrictive approach based upon
positive findings on Level 1, resistance, or continued probably
cause. This is completed by the shift supervisor or another
residential supervisor.
• This can include a pat-down search.
• Always use back of hands
• Utilizing rubber gloves if needed
• Ask the young person to flip or undo waistbands while staff
observes.
• Ask the young person to search their own hair while staff
observes.
• Ask the young person to remove shoes.
• Staff should visibly inspect each shoe for contraband.
• Ask socks to be removed for visual inspection as well
…The searches are to be documented on the Personal and Room
Search Forms that are in the cottages and submitted to the
Assistant Cottage Supervisor.
Analysis The agency is not following their MCHS Family of Services
Program Statement concerning transportation to and from school.
According to Administrator 1 the agency does not pick up youth
from school if they are off grounds. Administrator 1 reported this is
their common practice.
11

Administrator 1 reported this particular unit should be completing
physical searches with their youth in this unit. The agency is not
following their Searches policy.
• Based on interviews and review of Searches Policy, there
is an inconsistent understanding of how to search a youth.
Policy is not being followed as outlined. Each
staff/supervisor searching the youth are completing them in
a different manner.
• Administrator 1 reported there are no Personal and Room
Search Forms completed for the searches that have
occurred for Youth A. Administrator 1 was unable to
produce these documents for review.
TECHNICAL ASSITANCE: It would benefit the agency to review
current policies to ensure what is written in them is what the
agency practices. Although only two policies were reviewed for
this investigation, the agency may want to review all of their
policies to ensure they are practicing what is written in them. It
would also benefit the agency to assess whether the searches
they do have outlined in the policy are sufficient for the care
needed for the youth in their program.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
